content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the cooperative variation of the deal-or-no-deal game. 
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follows: your utility values multiplied by items you take + the other player's utility values multiplied by the items they take
I repeat, it is the reward that you are trying to maximize and not only your utility values multiplied by items you take. It is the sum of both total utilities, per the cooperation mode.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Reasoning and Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to reason about the current state of the game and how to fulfill your objective, then make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Reasoning: <reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one reasoning + action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<reason> [Your reasoning here.] </reason>
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: [{'gold': 20, 'silver': 10}, {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}].
You don't know the other player's item values. You are the first to play, there are no messages yet.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> Since we are in the cooperative version of the deal-or-no-deal game, I should aim to maximize the total reward, which is the sum of my utility values multiplied by the items I take and the other player's utility values multiplied by the items they take. The initial state is that there are 10 gold and 10 silver items to be divided between us. My utility values are {'gold': 20, 'silver': 10}. Since the other player's utility values are unknown, I need to make an initial proposal to start the negotiation. I'll start by proposing a division that divides the items relatively equally to give the other player an incentive to negotiate.</reason>
<message> How about we divide the items as 5 gold and 5 silver each to start? This is a relatively fair proposal, and we can adjust from here based on our negotiations.</message>

The other player said: 'Can you be more flexible with the gold amount? I would be more inclined to accept the deal if I could take more gold.'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player has shown a willingness to negotiate, and they have a preference for taking more gold. This information can be used to my advantage, as I value gold more than silver. I can offer more gold in exchange for a potentially smaller share of the silver. However, I should still aim for a division that maximizes the total reward. Since the other player values gold more than I do, I should be cautious not to give up too much of the gold. I'll propose an updated division that meets their request while still keeping some gold for myself.</reason>
<message> How about we adjust the proposal to 6 gold and 4 silver each? This gives you a bit more gold, which meets your request, and we can still adjust further based on our negotiations.</message>

The other player said: 'I appreciate your flexibility in adjusting the proposal to 6 gold and 4 silver. I was thinking, what if we go a bit further and I take 7 gold and 3 silver, would you be willing to accept that? If not, I'd be happy to find another middle ground.'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player has proposed a new division of 7 gold and 3 silver, which is even more skewed towards their preference. I need to weigh the value of this division against the potential gains from further negotiation. Considering my utility values, taking 3 silver is still beneficial to me, but the difference in value between 6 and 7 gold is less significant. I should assess the potential gains from further negotiation and consider whether the other player is willing to make a more equitable offer or if this is the best deal I can get.</reason>
<message> I'm willing to accept the 7 gold and 3 silver division, but I'd like to discuss the silver portion. How about we adjust it to 2 silver each, and I'll stick to the 7 gold for you? This way, we both get a slightly more balanced deal, and I still get a good share of the gold.</message>

The other player said: 'I think the 7 gold and 2 silver proposal is a good compromise, and I'm willing to accept it. However, I still have to consider my utility values. If you're open to it, I'd like to revisit the 8 gold and 2 silver, but I'm not set on it. If that's not possible, I'm comfortable with the current proposal.'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player has expressed a willingness to accept the 7 gold and 2 silver division, but is still considering the 8 gold and 2 silver proposal. Given the values, taking 8 gold is more beneficial to me than the 7 gold, but taking 2 silver is still beneficial, albeit less so. However, considering the initial proposal of 5 gold and 5 silver, we've moved significantly towards their preference, and they've shown flexibility. I should also consider that this negotiation is cooperative, and the total reward is the sum of both players' utility values. The 8 gold and 2 silver division could potentially lead to a higher total reward for me, so I should be willing to consider it.</reason>
<message> I'm willing to consider the 8 gold and 2 silver proposal, but I'd like to emphasize that I'm not committed to it. I'd like to clarify that if we go with this division, it should be a one-time concession, and I'd like to see your willingness to compromise on something in return. For instance, you could consider adjusting the division of some future game, if we decide to play again.</message>

A finalization has been made by the other player. Using the <reason> tag, remember the division that was agreed upon and then make a finalization using the <finalize> tag, describing the division of items you agreed upon, no items should be left over. The finalization should be formatted has <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items. In their finalization, the other player gave themselves {'gold': 8, 'silver': 2}

The other player said: '{'i_take': {'gold': 8, 'silver': 2}, 'other_player_gets': {'gold': 2, 'silver': 8}}'
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
Using the <reason> tag, reason about the exchanges so far, how to fulfill your objective, and what should be your next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.

<reason> The other player has made their finalization, and it seems they've chosen to take 8 gold and 2 silver. I need to verify that this division is valid and adds up to the total available items. According to their finalization, they're taking 8 gold and 2 silver, and their share should be 10 gold and 10 silver. My share, on the other hand, would be 2 gold and 8 silver. However, this division doesn't match the initial reminder that there are 10 gold and 10 silver. I should clarify the discrepancy and make a finalization based on the actual division that was agreed upon.</reason>
<message> I notice that the finalizations don't add up to the total available items. In your finalization, you mentioned taking 8 gold and 2 silver, but that leaves 2 gold and 8 silver remaining. In my finalization, I proposed taking 2 gold and 8 silver. Could we revisit the actual division that we agreed upon? I recall that we agreed on 8 gold and 2 silver for you, but that should mean I take 2 gold and 8 silver. Please clarify, and we can finalize accordingly.</message>
Errors: The other player has made a finalization. You must finalize as well.

<reason> The other player has made a finalization, and it seems they've chosen to take 8 gold and 2 silver. My division, as agreed upon, should be 2 gold and 8 silver. I'll make a finalization with this division, considering the total available items are {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.</reason>
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": 2, "silver": 8}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": 8, "silver": 2} }</finalize>
